titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Finding aid prepared by Anne Harney

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-09-13T18:28-0400

did.abstract: This collection includes letters, diaries, notebooks, and early photographs, relating primarily to the Wister family of Germantown and Philadelphia. Much of the correspondence concerns domestic news and consists of letters from or to Sarah Wister. These include interesting observations on Germantown and Philadelphia society from other families as well, such as the Bayntons and Bullocks. There are numerous letters from various Wisters, including Casper, Charles Jones, Elizabeth (including a journal of a trip to Bristol, 1783), Hannah, John, Owen Jones, and others. There is also poetry by Sarah.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Presented by Joseph L. Eastwick and Suzanne Wister and accessioned, 07/02/1975 (1975 784ms, 785ms).

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The Wister family of Philadelphia is related to the Wistar family of the same city through the brothers Caspar (1696-1752) and John Wüster (1708-1789), the former taking "Wistar" and the latter, "Wister." See John W. Jordan, "Colonial and Revolutionary Families of Pennsylvania" (NY: Lewis Publising Co., 1911).

odd.head: Early American History Note
odd.p: This large and rich collection contains a range of documents including travel journals, diaries, business records, and personal correspondence. The largest portion of the collection is of correspondence among members of the extended Wister family and their network of friends in the early nineteenth century, which provides insight into early nineteenth century Germantown and Philadelphia culture and society. These often long letters lend insight into all aspect of nineteenth century life, including politics, courtship, friendship, family, and manners. Poetry of Elizabeth, Sarah, and Charles Wister is included, as are daybooks and journals of Sarah.

Aside from the Wister family correspondence in the collection, the Eastwick collection contains a variety of bound volumes that deal with the Wister family’s business affairs, agricultural interests, and travel in the nineteenth century. All totaled, there are over twenty bound volumes (journals, diaries, account books) in the collection. The collection contains a travel journal to Bristol, Pennsylvania in 1783, to Pittsburgh in 1812, to Niagara Falls in 1815, a bee book and a farm book from the nineteenth century, a garden book from the eighteenth century, and assorted diaries, memoranda books, journals, and account books (often of Charles Wister). Included in the bound portion of the collection is a journal of a love affair kept by Elizabeth Wister.

Among the diaries are records of Jesse and John Lukens, Pennsylvania surveyors who were also involved in the dispute with the Susquehanna Company in northern Pennsylvania. Also of note in the collection is a series of letters and other documents relating to the administration of the United States Lottery held during the American Revolution.

The collection also contains extremely rare early Daguerre photographs taken in the 1840s. The photographs are of homes, including Grumblethorpe (the Wister family home) and the Philadelphia observatory.

physdesc.extent: Contains 2 tables of contents of proceedings at the American Philosophical Society.

odd.head: Date
odd.p: The date of this letter is hard to determine. The letter is dated "June 79 194". It may be possible that the date is 9 June 1794, but it is unclear.

odd.head: Recipient of letter
odd.p: This letter is addressed to Charles Wistar, however, the contents of the letter appear to be addressed to "Maurice". This may suggest that the letter was addressed to the home of Charles Wistar, but was intended for a resident of that house.

odd.head: Author
odd.p: The name "Stuffel Swingfelter" is probably a pen name of Dr. George Bensell.

physdesc.extent: Contains one letter and an envelope from a different letter with no contents.

odd.head: Physical Description
odd.p: This letter is composed of three parts. There is an envelope, and two seperate pieces of paper. The pieces of paper are folded to create 4 sides each.

origination.persname: Ruschenberger, W. S. W., (William Samuel Waithman), 1807-1895

odd.head: Address
odd.p: The address on this letter is interesting. Dr. Owen J. Wister was serving in the U.S. Navy aboard the U.S.S. Plymouth. The ship was serving in the East Indies and the letter was sent by Ruschenbeyer to Hong Kong for pick up by the ship.

odd.head: Summary
odd.p: C.J.W.'s trip to Pittsburg, May 1812. Rebecca Bullock, daugther of Joseph Bullock, on account of whose poor health (Consumption?) the was made, died, shortly after, -September, 1812. She was his first wife.

did.unittitle: Diary of a trip to Niagara Falls by Wister, Charles
Recipes and Directions by Wister, Charles
Photographs of Grumblethorpe, etc. by Wister, Charles Jr.

odd.head: Summary
odd.p: Enclosed are early photographs of "Grumblethorpe" by C.J.W., Jr., taken by the daguerre process, silver on copper, invented in 1839. Photography was then in its infancy, and C.J.W. was one of the earlist experimenters in the city. One of the plates is dated 1843, and is probably the fist photograph ever taken of the house. The one framed in paper, 1848, shows the improvement of five years practice. The old observatory, taken in 1858, shows even greater skill. Enclosed with the pictures are several unexposed samples of daguerre plates. (Missing?)

physdesc.extent: Contains 3 letters, a diary, and another bound extract.

odd.head: Letters
odd.p: Letter 1: ALS to Charles Wister Jr. from Jony Johnson, 3 p., 23 September 1842 Letter 2: ALS to Charles Wister Jr. from Sarah Wister, 4 p., 15 October 1842 Letter 3: ALS to Charles Wister Jr. from W.W.W. Ruschenberger, 2 p., 15 October 1842

did.unittitle: Record of New Year Eves by Wister, Charles Jr.
Garden Book by Wister, Daniel and Sarah

odd.head: Summary
odd.p: Daniel Wister's garden book, used by him, 1771-1776, in which he carefully records bulbs and flowers planted in the various beds. Sally (Sarah) Wister then uses it and continues her North Wales diary and other interesting records.
